During the Cold War, Latin America experienced significant political, economic, and social turmoil that paved the way for the emergence of military dictatorships in the region. The United States was strongly committed to curtailing the spread of communism in the hemisphere and supported various military coups across the region, providing both financial and material aid to right-wing regimes that promised to eradicate communism and maintain stability in their countries.

Beginning in the 1960s and throughout the 1970s, countries such as Brazil, Chile, Argentina, and Uruguay witnessed an increase in the power of the military in their societies. Military regimes emerged and exerted authoritarian control over these countries, often utilizing violence, fear, and intimidation to quell any opposition.

These dictatorships were able to maintain their power by creating powerful intelligence agencies and secret police forces, which helped them identify and eliminate perceived threats to their rule. These regimes also dismantled democratic institutions and suspended civil liberties, such as freedom of speech and assembly, to suppress dissent.

Moreover, these regimes implemented economic policies designed to benefit the ruling elite, such as deregulation, privatization, and trade liberalization. These measures often led to the concentration of wealth in the hands of a few, sparking widespread inequality and social unrest.

The rise of military dictatorships ultimately led to widespread human rights abuses and a legacy of state terror across the region, with thousands of people subject to torture, forced disappearances, and extrajudicial killings. Even though some of these dictatorships were eventually overthrown, the impact of their legacy continues to be felt in Latin American societies to this day.
